Production, Acclaim, Genre, etc.
Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works (first season) is a twelve-episode anime that aired from October to December 2014. It was created by studio Ufotable, famous for fantasy anime such as Tales of Symphonia, Kara no Kyoukai, and various installments of the Fate series. FSN:UBW is a newer adaptation of the 2010 movie Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works and the 2006 series Fate/Stay Night. These, in turn, were adaptations of the original visual novel/ Windows game by Type Moon.
 The Fate franchise is widely popular. A hundred and seventy-five thousand users on myanimelist.net have rated this series for an average of 8.41, makingit nearly as popular as such classic series as Madoka Magica, Code Geass, and Death Note. Its rating is higher than that of newly hyped anime such as Akame ga Kill. Genres and themes for FSN:UBW include fantasy, suspense, battle royale, friendship, action, and part psychological thriller. To fully appreciate FSN:UBW, you will have to watch the second season, but this review will focus solely on the first season of twelve episodes. 


Story: Execution and Structure


The story in FSN:UBW was well-planned and well-executed. It succeeds in being a captivating fantasy and a suspenseful, exciting battle royale.  Even if you're not into fantasy or competitive battles, it's possible to just enjoy the story of Shirou's personal journey along with that of Archer. It can be quite thought-provoking and has a psychological element. The story will force you to think about what your values are, whether or not you live them out, and whether they are feasible or unrealistic. FSN:UBW can also be enjoyed as the second half of the story of Fate/Zero. 


As a writer, I'm interested in story composition, and would like to discuss that here. Interpretations of the story structure of FSN's first season may differ, but I look at it from the perspective that Shirou's personal journey is the main "plot." From that perspective, there are three major plot points: summoning Saber in episode 1, beginning his conflict with Archer in episode 7, and, in episode 12, losing something dear to him partly as a result of his insistence on his ideals. The three plot point structure of Shirou's journey is a great way to develop his character, and can be thought of as 1) becoming someone with the potential to be a hero, 2) conflict with someone challenging his heroic ideals, and 3) seeing the consequences of being too much of a selfless person.  


(Now, if action is the main driving plot, then the story's biggest points are probably fighting Berserker in episode 3, fighting Rin and Rider in episode 6, fighting Rider in episode 8, fighting Caster's Master in episode 10, and finally, being attacked by Caster in episode 12. The 3-6-8-10-12 pattern is excellent design for an action show with a lot of fighting. It makes it so there is room for both character development and action, and it tries to get viewers hooked with the important third episode.)


Art: Overall and Character Designs


FSN:UBW is a beautiful, colorful treat for the eyes. The vivid coloring makes almost any screenshot worthy of being a wallpaper. The studio kept the same basic animation style as the 2010 movie, the relatively modern style of somewhat realistic body proportions but classic anime facial features of large, sparkling eyes and tiny noses. The detail and picture quality were improved compared to the 2010 movie. Unlike in the movie, some CG is used for effects, such as the wisps of air around Saber's invisible sword, the disappearing and reappearing of Heroic Spirits, and some of the colorful, special attacks of the characters. Importantly, however, CG is not overused, and for the most part it blends in well. The fight scenes look amazing, and although they are fantasy battles rather than techniques used in a real fighting form, they still look well-referenced. I would have liked more realism personally. 


The character designs keep to the originals by Takashi Takeuchi from what I can tell. They are certainly memorable, though to me they seem somewhat plain and simple once you take away the almost blindingly bright colors. For example, Rin's red outfit really fit her personality, and helps viewers develop an image of what she's like, but without that, would she still be properly expressive? I would have liked to see more details and differences in the faces and expressions of the characters. I have no complaints about the overall design though. Lancer, a popular character among fans, has a particularly appealing character design for me, and he is one of the characters whose expressions are more pronounced. I have always been a fan of Saber, and she wouldn't be the same without that design. 


Sound: Acting, Music, and Scores 


Though there was nothing that struck me as amazing or unforgettable, the voice acting in FSN:UBW is still pretty good. The same voices used in the 2010 movie are used in the 2014 adaptation. Rin's seiyuu Kana Ueda played the lead character in Maria Sama ga Miteru, Shigofumi, and Kashimashi Girl Meets Girl. Noriaki Sugiyama, voice of Shirou Emiya, is famous for voices in the Naruto series, though he hasn't had many lead roles in other anime. Junichi Suwabe plays Archer, is widely known for playing Dandy in Space Dandy, and has side roles in many excellent anime including Bungou Stray Dogs, Danganrompa 3, Kiznaiver, High School of the Dead, and Black Butler. Among the main characters' seiyuu, I believe Suwabe's performance was probably the best. The widely popular seiyuu Hiroshi Kamiya makes a minor appearance as Shinji Matou. Even with such a small role, he makes himself memorable. 


FSN's opening theme, "Ideal White," was performed by Ayano Mashiro with lyrics by Meg Rock and music composition by Carlos K. At first, the song didn't stick out at me, but after listening to it a few times, it started to become the very sound of FSN for me. It's quite suitable for an action-fantasy anime and has a positive feel to it. The lyrics are interesting, and I see them as Shirou's own thoughts. The band Kalafina performed the first ending theme, "Believe," with composition and lyrics created by Yuki Kajiura. Kalafina is known for performing songs for anime such as Madoka Magica and Kara no Kyoukai. The song is memorable and pleasant to listen to, especially if you enjoyed hearing the band in Madoka Magica. 


The OST for FNS:UBW was composed by Hideyuki Fukasawa. (There is an OST II for season 2.) The music didn't stick out at me as much as with some anime, but whenever I listen to the OST, I am always impressed with it. It could be that the music scores matched the scenes and emotions so perfectly that they escaped my notice while I watched. One of my favorite things about the music is that electric guitar is often used in addition to orchestra. The track "Archer" is one of my favorites, an exciting and mysterious rhythm building up steadily. "Two Hearts" and "Far Away from You" are other tracks that touch me; they are beautifully orchestrated, emotional melodies, with "Far Away" having more of an emotional climax.  


Characters: General, Rin, and Shirou 


Almost all of the characters in FSN:UBW are memorable, though many of them are underdeveloped or one-dimensional. The chivalry, loyalty, and courage of Saber make her an appealing character for anyone who admires knights and classic, good-hearted heroes. In contrast, the rough and rugged Archer appeals to those who like their heroes with a dark and unpredictable side. I felt that several of the minor characters in FSN:UBW deserved more attention than they got. The best example is Taiga Fujimura, Shirou's legal guardian and older-sister-figure. She was funny, spirited, cheery, well-designed, and a great contrast to the angsty, gloomy, or angry teenagers in the house. Another underdeveloped character is the Assassin servant that guards Caster's temple. He had an interesting character concept, but only gets significant screen time in one or two episodes of the first season. 


Something deserves to be said about the main heroes, Rin Tohsaka and Shirou Emiya. Although the situation does seem to be slowly improving in some genres, anime in general has few strong, leading female protagonists, and the ones that exist are often disliked as stubborn "bitches" by the male fanbase, showing the ever-present problem of sexism. For that reason, it's a breath of fresh air to have a spirited, free-thinking heroine like Rin. For most of the series, she is a superior mage compared to male protagonist Shirou, and she never backs away from a fight. Her values system makes her seem cold-hearted, but she adjusts them as the series goes on to make room for words and actions that show her human heart. It's also refreshing that Tohsaka is designed and regarded in the show as a beautiful person, without needing huge jelly-boobs or revealing clothes—fan services that are sickeningly common in modern anime. 


The male hero, Shirou Emiya, is a bit unusual in some ways compared to lead characters in many (but not all) anime series. He is reasonably humble, rarely needing to act "manly" to prove himself. Though he starts off skeptical and misjudging of Saber because of her gender, Shirou comes to accept and respect her soon enough, relying on her strength. Throughout the season, it is suggested that Shirou is driven first and foremost by his values, which are shown to be unrealistically idealistic in some cases. It's rare to see a protagonist so driven by pure intentions, with the flaw of not being able to accept that his values might be flawed. This stubbornness gives him an air of strength and determination, though it also shows he still very much a child at heart. I have encountered few anime with a hero like Shirou, who strives for an ideal, and shows courage and determination even in the light of weakness or lack of ability.  


Enjoyment


Watching FSN:UBW was certainly a treat for the eyes, and in some ways a breath of fresh air, but in other ways, I found myself a bit disappointed, or even bored. While the battles are colorful and explosive, they don't have any quality of realism that makes me feel suspense. The Holy Grail War is supposed to be a Battle Royale, but all the characters seemed to me to be slow in making their moves and following through. Once I got a sense of Shirou's character, the direction of the story became quite predictable, at least in season one. There were only one or two twists that truly surprised me. In addition, I used to be a lot like Shirou, and watching his character's journey with its many mistakes (like my own) was a bit painful. That doesn't make the show any less awesome; it just interfered with my personal enjoyment somewhat.


 I liked season two, the second half of FSN:UBW much better, and I definitely recommend continuing the story whether you already know it from the movie or whether you're a brand new fan.

-No spoilers-
Honestly, I do not give straight 10's easily. This show is quite a rare find within the many anime's that are out there. This anime is a needle in a haystack and when you do find the needle... it's made out pure gold and you cannot help but pinch yourself with it to make sure its real... and if you're dreaming.
Anyway, enough of that, this is my 2nd time watching Fate/stay night: Unlimited Blade Works. I'd like to note that unfotable went above and beyond. This high caliber art of an anime is breathtakingly beautiful. The effects are of utmost perfection. I cannot thinkof anything bad about this besides the fact that it is an anime based off of a visual novel. I very much so would like to see a season 3 because at the end of the season 2 the show sorta ended on a cliffhanger. \n\n
I personally think this show is a gold mine waiting to happen. I would 100% think this would be on par with the amount of sales that Sword Art Online is receiving. Get a team of writers together and start writing! \n\n
Also, both the dub and sub are phenomenal. For this one, I preferred the dub just because it was on Netflix.

Some people feel that Unlimited Blade Works (hereafter UBW) is not deserving of its high score.  I think your potential enjoyment of this anime is going to largely depend on how important coherent story is to you.
Many of us watch anime because it is adventurous, and it represents a medium through which to express situations and possibilities not present in "real life."  So I don't really understand the negative reviewers who are very much preoccupied with a lack of realism, plot holes, or literary quality.
So let's get the negatives out of the way then.  
- The main story, the Grail War, isunconvincing, melodramatic, and gives low return on your investment of time.  There is no denying this.

- UBW is excessively talky and has some of the worst in-combat dialogue I've ever witnessed.  Anime as a genre is particularly guilty of monologues during fight scenes, but UBW is among the worst.

- There are no surprising outcomes in the main plot.  You can write it yourself, it's that bad.

- Archer's angsty backstory is just cringe-worthy.  Just, No.


OK, so if the negatives are so atrocious, why did I rate this anime so highly?


Really it comes down to two things: Atmosphere and Characters.  For me, I watch anime because I want to go on an adventures with the characters in the story.  I call it atmosphere but maybe some other applicable phrases might be "setting feeling", "world building", or "adventure quotient."  Say you are having a dream.  How amazing was it?  Some of this is personal preference.  I love the fact that some of the combatants, Rin especially, are self-sufficient mages living in their own mansions.  I don't care how realistic this is--as a setting it's amazing to me.  


Regarding the characters, the main appeal to me I suppose is the fact that I am not familiar with the VN / Type Moon games, having never played them.  I watched the original Fate/stay night and zero, and I wasn't very impressed with the characters, story, or anything else really.  However, I wasn't prepared for this path where Rin's relationship with Shirou is explored.  It caught me by surprise in the most pleasant way possible.  And it is NOT fan-servicey as other cheaper anime are.  I actually found myself eager for the next episode just to see how their relationship would develop.  And I was fearful of the way this is resolved in Season 2 of UBW but in my opinion it turns out with the best outcome I could have hoped for.


As for actual character development, well, it's a bit forced and contrived just as you would expect with the terrible writing of the source material.  But ufotable takes some liberties with the dialogue I think, making it much easier to watch the slice-of-life parts vs. the actual battles and main conflicts (which are cringe-inducing).


The annoying magenta-haired girl, (of Heaven's Feel path) is largely pushed into the background here, for which I'm very grateful.


I actually like Saber better in UBW because her relationship with Shirou feels much more natural and relatable.


OK, some technical positives:


+ Battle animation / fight scenes are top notch.  Seriously, the fights are much more coherent, the animation looks fluid, and the visual effects have a lot of dynamic lighting.  Probably CG is everywhere but it is blended with hand-drawn art masterfully.  10/10 of all anime I have ever seen.


+ Character designs are very appealing.  Probably personal preference, but I have a hard time watching anime with crappy character designs


+ The sound track is to die for.  If the story absolutely sucks, the original sound track is on the complete opposite end of the spectrum.  Sometimes I'll throw the OST on in my car when I want to be inspired.  It's that good.


OK, to summarize, if you love being transported to another place for exciting adventures, you much watch this.  If you are one of those stuffy pseudo-intellectual types who are no fun at parties and like to point out every logical inconsistency, well, this is not your anime.

Let me start off by saying that I'm a huge Fate series fan and that there'll be a few minor "spoilers" that I personally don't believe will negatively affect your enjoyment of the show. I did try to keep spoilers to a minimum, however, if you want to play it safe, please skip to the last two paragraphs.
Like I said before, I'm huge Fate series fan. I've played both the original Visual Novels, their remasters, I've read the light novels, played their video games, and of course, watched their anime.
That said, I can't bring myself to like this show. I still love the Visual Novel,I thoroughly enjoyed the Unlimited Blade Works route, but this anime is its own thing. 


The dialogue was rewritten, scenes were rewritten, they've added in scenes(which were frankly unnecessary) that were never in the original source material and they even decided to make changes to the main heroine, Rin. 


The Rin in the visual novel showed tsundere tendencies at times, but she wasn't this over-the-top. Her body language was, generally speaking, never this energetic, she was more confident, was more successful in her attempts to appear graceful, and was all around less generic, more believable, and more impressive(to me) as a character. 


That said the adaptation's Rin is not what I would call a terrible or even bad character. My point is that what, I hope, was their attempt to improve upon an already great one, only served to make her, overall, less likable. 


The dialogue is terrible. In fact, I honestly do believe that the infamous Fate/Stay Night adaptation made by Studio Deen in 2006 is better in this aspect. I realize that, as a non-native speaker of Japanese, I may not be qualified to criticize the dialogue of a Japanese show. But I personally believe that the dialogue was so poorly done that even an individual with no knowledge of Japanese whatsoever, would be able to tell that there was something off. Forceful transitions into exposition and awkward dialogue pacing make for a deadly combination. This was, most probably, the greatest reason why I was not fully immersed. Most of the time, I was unable to believe that these characters were actually having a conversation. The original Visual Novel's dialogue was never perfect, and, like this adaption, had problems with subtlety, but it was still of an adequate level of quality, so I was able to immerse myself. 


If you can look past the dialogue, I do believe there is quite a bit to enjoy. 


I don't usually focus on animation, but it is called "Unlimited Budget Works" for a reason. I do believe that the action scenes were well done, the backgrounds were detailed, there were plenty of wallpaper-worthy scenes, I liked their use of CG and all in all, I personally believe it does look beautiful, but I am still reluctant to call it "good" because I'm far from an expert.


When the show tries to be funny, I did laugh quite a bit. I like how Shirou and Rin were developed. I like how they explored Shirou and Archer's characters. Though it was done rather clumsily, I do like how they tried to explore some of the problems of altruism. How they tried to tell its audience that, even if it's impossible to save everyone, you're not necessarily wrong for believing that it's still a goal worth working towards. Sure, it can sound rather stupid. Even characters portrayed as respectable and intelligent in the show think it's stupid. But personally, I like it.


In conclusion, it can be funny, there were some great ideas, a unique message, it's supposedly very well animated, and I like how they tried to explore and develop the characters of Shirou, Rin, and Archer. However, I was unable to immerse myself into the show. The dialogue was so awkwardly paced and terribly written, I was unable to trick myself into believing that the characters in the show were actually having a dialogue no matter how hard I tried, despite not being a native speaker of Japanese. I just could not enjoy it as much as I wanted to. There is enjoyment to be had, but it does spoil the Visual Novel and I don't think it's anywhere near as good, so I still find it difficult to recommend it to anyone. Fate/Zero is a much better introduction to the Fate series for anyone who doesn't have the time to read a Visual Novel.


For those who do, you can simply purchase a cheap(comparatively at least) PS2 copy of the game to support the creators. It's, supposedly, extremely easy to pirate the game online, but I'm not necessarily recommending that anyone do that. It is still illegal after all.

This is an anime that treats itself as a novel. Understand that, and you'll understand that this is not made for "anime fans", and it treats itself very differently from many others. (This is in part due to the fact that it's based on a video game that had three main branching paths, with over 40 different endings.) 
It initially falls victim to several stereotypical anime tropes, but quickly outgrows them. Whatever you hear, this is NOT a harem anime. Several girls early in the anime express interest in the protagonist (again, possibly due to the many branching storylines of the original game), but itmoves on from that scenario extremely quickly. 


I don't know where to start with my love for this anime. The plot is intense, with some twists you'll see coming and plenty you won't. The stakes feel high enough--not always necessarily in body count, but definitely on a personal level. 


However, the greatest thing this anime has to offer is in its characters. Almost every single character is well-developed, which is a remarkably fresh breath of air in anime. I am not simply referring to "backstory", but rather each character has a strong and distinct personality without relying heavily on stereotypes or caricatures. It is said that the best novels have every character believe that the novel is about them. Everyone is at the center of their own life story, so fictional characters should be more concerned about their life stories than the anime's actual plot. That is 100% how Unlimited Blade Works plays out, and I love it. Every character's actions is based on their own goals and motivations, and nobody... NOBODY... acts as if they are a secondary character in the story. This anime has, without a doubt, the single most realistic characters I have seen yet.   


My greatest hesitation is likely with the explanation of certain plot points. It very easily could have been the translation on the version I watched (Crunchyroll) but some things didn't seem to make sense to me OR my viewing partner. Like I said, these could have been translation issues rather than an issue with the actual anime (I'm not skilled enough in Japanese to tell.) However, talking with my viewing parter, we were able to make sense of everything. Also, Fate does fall into the trap of occasionally repeating itself too much, but I found myself laughing those moments off rather than being bothered by them--they didn't ruin my overall enjoyment at all.   


If you are looking for your standard Pretty Boy vs. Rage Monster anime, look elsewhere. If you are looking for a harem anime, look elsewhere. If you are looking for an anime that prioritizes plot over character, look elsewhere. If you want a well-thought-out, intensely personal anime, filled with characters that are so realistic you'll feel like you could run into them on the street--punctuated by extremely epic fight setpieces and a few good twists--this is what you've been looking for.

I am the bone of my sword
 Steel is my body and fire is my blood 
 I have created over a thousand blades
 Unknown to Death,
 Nor known to Life.
 Have withstood pain to create many weapons 
 Yet, those hands will never hold anything 
 So as I pray, Unlimited Blade Works.
(Note, this review is for both seasons of UBW. You have been warned)
One of the unique things about Fate/Stay Night (The Visual Novel) (And really, anything made by Type-Moon) was that there was technically 3 versions of it, all written by the same author of course. Each of them shifted focusto different characters and the plot became more complex and darker with each. Here, we're talking about the adaptation of my favorite route... and how it became one of my favorite animes of all time.


Story:


If there's anything I could compare the routes of Fate to, it would probably be that the Fate route is the original Gundam series, UBW is Gundam The Origin and HF is Gundam SEED. As the comparison would imply, it often feels like an expansion of the Fate route, but its probably so in the best possible ways. Many of the concepts introduced there are expanded upon, and the pacing is much faster.

As the Gundam The Origin comparison would imply, UBW is also way darker than the Fate route, yet at the same time, it never feels mean spirited, and there's always enough hope that you want to keep watching so that you watch your favorite characters survive.

The show also heavily deconstructs Shirou's ideals, but unlike Heaven's Feel, it ultimately also reconstructs them, and shows all of them great things that come with them alongside all of the bad in them.

The rivalry between Shirou and Archer is, for the lack of a better word, perfect. The two are indeed two sides of the very same coin, with Archer showing what could happen when someone decides to persue an ideal, yet has nothing left to live for. It ultimately becomes pretty much the main subplot of UBW, and I wouldn't want it any other way.


Characters:


The characters are mostly the same as in the Fate route, but with some differences. Shirou thankfully doesn't suffer much of a downgrade from the VN here even though his internal monologue is still missing, likely because they made a much bigger effort than the DEEN anime to translate his thoughts into dialogue. UBW is technically meant to be the Rin route, but when you get right down to it, this is Shirou's route. This is about his struggles, his efforts to try and honor Kiritsugu's ideals, which all leads to a brilliant conclusion.

Rin and Saber both made for good female leads. Saber doesn't get as much focus as in the Fate route, but she gets enough for my taste and she's still ultimately a likable character. Rin thankfully gets a lot more to do, and is generally far more competent. Her romance with Shirou isn't as integral to the show as Shirou and Saber's was in the Fate route, but it's surprisingly well done.

But of course, you can't talk about UBW without mentioning its deutragonist, Archer. This is the most focus Archer has ever gotten, and thank God for that. The show really does delve into how much of an utterly broken and cynical individual he truly is. And his struggles throughout the show end up being just as endearing as Shirou's.

Gilgamesh gets a lot more to do too, and he's basically the main villain here. He's an interesting character. His motivations are certainly twisted, but there's definitely a hint of truth in them, and you can't help but understand why he ultimately thinks so. Plus he's a deliciously large ham to booth.

But screw them, let's talk about the true star of the show, the hound of Cuulan (I think that's how it's spelled) himself, Lancer. Oh my God I adore this guy. He's technically a villain, but he's so affable and easygoing that you wish he wasn't. Combine this with and absolutely badass weapons and one of the coolest deaths in the franchise's history, it's easy to see why he's one of my favorite characters ever.


Animation:


Remember how the animation was the worst point of the DEEN anime? Well, here, it's the exact opposite. This is some of the most fluid, energetic and straight up gorgeous animation I've ever seen on a TV anime. It's honestly on par with some OVAs I've seen. The fights are extremely flashy, yet they're also believable enough to be engaging. Needless to say, this show has earned its nickname of Unlimited Budget Works.


Soundtrack:


Most of the soundtrack is composed of remixes from tracks from the VN, though I did notice some Fate/Zero tracks here and there. I of course don't mind that since those soundtracks were perfect. The new openings and endings are also great too. Also, "Last Stardust" is one of the greatest songs I've ever heard.


Voice Acting:


All but one of the voice actors from the VN return and do an outstanding job. The one that didn't come back was Kuzuki, who's now played by Masaki Terasoma, as apparently Kazuhiro Nakata had some health troubles. He's not as good as Nakata, but he gets the job done. 

Of particular mention are Noriaki Sugiyama as Shirou and Junichi Suwabe as Archer, as those two are pretty much the heart and soul of UBW. Oh, and this is the show in which I jumped into the Nobutoshi Canna fan train.


Overall;


Haven't I made my point yet? You MUST watch this show. It definitely shouldn't be your first experience though, start with the DEEN anime, then watched Fate/Zero and then finally watch this show. Trust me, its worth it.


Final Score: 10/10

Ok. So here's how I see it.
I think UBW is a great anime, but maybe not for the reason you might think.
*slight spoiler ahead*
Allow me the audacity to say that the characters are complete trash. Nothing's interesting about our main character and his posse, and the characters that are actually interesting all go away within a couple episodes. Exactly 0 of them get to do any developing. This really makes it hard to watch and enjoy the story after sometime, which is a shame because the Fate series has some of the most awesome, tragic, happy, basically all of those emotions wrapped into one, kindof story. The fact that Emiya is still the stubborn and "people die when they are killed" character, and that there was 0 change in his attitude even after all of the stuff he goes through, says to me that none of that needed to happen. The story went forward, yet the characters stay still. UBW isn't better than the 2006 Fate in that aspect.\n
This sort of gap between character and story ruined the experience for me.\n\n
HOWEVER.\n
UBW has probably the most orgasmic animation I have ever seen. The art direction, the choreography, the sound effects, shows me the peak capabilities of artists in their craft. I promise, you will not easily find another anime comparable to UBW's high quality animation. \n\n
So, this is why I think UBW is great... for a starter anime. Watch and show your anime curious friends the first half of this series (or all, i don't care). Show them exactly how much can be achieved through this medium. Even the story is pretty amazing (though if you let them watch for long enough, maybe they'll figure out how static the characters are) and the characters you do get attached to. But as a "child" in anime, you need the sugary sweets before you can truly enjoy the more complicated palet.\n
Then maybe, you'll be able to move on to a more "adult" anime, like Mars of Destruction, the best anime ever made in our lifetime and many lifetimes before.

To put it simply this entire series could be summed up as "Awesome animation Meh Plot and Meh Characters".  The fighting sequences are what you should watch this anime for not for it's plot. If you've watched the other Fate Series then should already know this well, however this one in particular has even less plot/story substance than the other series. Although i believe it is on par/slightly surpasses the others in terms of fight sequences. The main Protagonist is okay but he's a bit timid and for the most part a walking contradiction who is very confused about who he is as anindividual which at times can be a bit annoying. However he shines when paired with the female lead in this anime as their relationship is essentially the focal point of this anime and where it does its best. The over ending/conclusion of the series was meh, and i feel as though the last episode wasn't necessary and it was fine to end it on the episode before as the final episode was a bit empty and unfulfilling. Overall i give this anime a 7 simply for enjoyment, but if you want something that is very thought provoking with an awesome storyline this isn't for you, this is for the action junkies.

This is the first version of the fate/stay night series that I have watched. I had heard a lot of negative things about the earlier Studio Deen adaptation, so I basically avoided the series until UBW came out. I initially was interested in the premise of the story -- Mages summoning great heroes from the past to fight the holy grail war to obtain an item that will grant its user any wish, so I wanted to see how it would play out, especially considering this story is based on an "adult" light novel. 
Basically, the best thing about this anime is that THE ARTIS SO BEAUTIFUL. From the smoothly executed and finely detailed fight scenes to the wonderful stills, this was probably the most visually stunning anime I had seen all year. Watching this anime was definitely a treat for the eyes and does not disappoint in this department. I literally wanted to watch the next episode every single time just to see what it looked like. 


Being that this was the first adaptation of FSN I have seen, I was a little confused about some of the roles of the characters and their importance in the overall picture. So I have to confess that I had to do a little research in order to really understand the plot and character relations. Characters such as Sakura, Ilya, and Kotomine have such as underdeveloped and minor role in this series, despite their importance in other arcs to the point where I almost didn't really care about and see the point of these characters being there. 


Despite the flaws in the plot and the character development, I do like how the relationship between the leads, Shirou and Rin play out (since this was basically a big focus of the series) a lot better that the relationship between Shirou and Saber in the Studio Deen adaptation of the Fate Route. Rin doesn't depend on Shirou too much to save her and Shirou lets Rin do whatever the heck she wants for the most part because of the trust between them. 


Although the ending felt kind of abrupt, I thought it was still somewhat satisfying compared to other anime I have watched. 


So as a whole, I thought this anime was very enjoyable despite its flaws and I think that the visuals that this anime has to offer definitely makes it one to check out.

Ufotable is showing the chink in its armor with this one.
Let me tell you about a very important thing that many studios have problems with but has always been able to mask it with the source materials or the visual or the soundtrack.
Writing.
For me writing should be at a point where it adds into the events happening. After all, most world building and even settling are done through dialogues. This holds especially through with anime. For some reason Japanese visual arts are still obsessed with exposition, namely novel. Unlike visual arts where parts of the exposition could be told through the background or sound, wordsneed to be write or said to be used to describe the actual things and subjects. The cleverness of words stern from the fact that a writer could tell so much with so little. Incorporate these elements into visual arts requires a great deal of skills and thoughts to make the best of it. \n
Fate Stay Night Unlimited Blade Works\n
Perhaps it is the fact that many people has not try out Fate Stay Night Visual Novel that lead to the rise of this particular one popularity. In all my honestly I could only describe it in one word: excruciating. It was one of the most cringe worthy adaption I could recall to date, even trump the original because that one at least has the charm of a silly, clumsy visual novel adaption. After Fate Zero I would thought Ufotable would completely revitalize in my opinion the best route in the visual novel. But at last it flop quite spectacularly in ways I didn't expect.\n
The story is the strength of this one unfortunately and this one I can't credit Ufotable for it. This route with all of the spoiler in the world is about the main character and his path to reaffirm his own belief, forging his own weapon, personality and most importantly resolve as a person. It is such a personal and intriguing story that makes you feel this character is a person, a relate-able man rather than that silly guy with a silly idea about life. Nativity, youth and inner desire are pit against maturity, cynicism and circumstances in a battle that are build up step by step, slowly reaching its peak with all the seasoning of a struggle, feeling of lost and hopelessness. No other route has been able to freshen the main character up as much as this one. Fate feels like a trip to the countryside, quickly forgotten the moment I fall asleep on the way home. Heavenly feels is like a guided tour through a city with many attractions. Everything is almost touched and go, leaving me half wanted for more and half desired to have nothing to do with it anymore. So this one is really worth watching for someone who do not have the time to read the novel. \n
I wouldn't be able to say the same to the writing however. There are many dialogue that sounds like it was taken directly from the novel. Jesus christ, the visual novel needed to spelled out almost everything like Hideo Kajima on weed but it needed to do that because Kinoko Nasu is not a good exposition man even though he tried really hard. If you are capable of appreciate his writing then congratulation you are fitted to read 90% of the light novel out there. If you are not then like me you can go and do something meaningful instead of reading that loads of crap that sometime mixed with some rare sparkling stones, mind you stones, not gems. The effect of this importation is that sometime character makes this kind of comment such as "he's capable of doing xyz, looks like we can't zxy" and bloody hell did they repeatedly doing this almost every time we are introduced to someone powerful. It is so hard to swallow it all when the dialogues tickle my inner ear every 10 minutes. I never knew I hated the visual novel style of dialogue so much before watching this. It makes me lose all respect for ufotable and ended up watching their previous stuffs to reminds myself of what was done well. Kara no Kyoukai for example is rather dialog heavy as well and one part people seems to have forgotten about it is that the dialogues were the central peace of that work. Look past the cool effects we find a soft, quiet, atmospheric, intriguing show that easily eaten up every other show trying to imitate it. Admittedly it is still hindered by Nasu ineptitude for exposition that sometimes kill the atmosphere. Still its dialogues were tight, interesting and worth listening to. Unlimited Blade Work TV version dialogue is atrociously awkward especially when it comes to Rin. She used to be cool and fun to see but now she's like a talkative awkward person that is neither interesting nor fun because of the dialogues she give. They could cut out tons of dialogues but they chose not to. Maybe it has to do with the "purist" who wants every single minor detail from their favorite book or whatever to be adapted. It makes them feel warm in their pants or something. Some people mistaken these long exposition for pacing because they see them as things that happen between battle scenes. The battle is merely a device to further the plot and characters you know? Most if not all of the important plot points are made from the aftermath or as preparation for the next battle but the focus is still on characters and plot and not the cool visual effects. That is why I still respect and read Nasu works even though they make sleepy all the time, kind of the same thing I would say about Mr Kojima too. The conversations though completely kills it for me and it is the writing fault. \n
Visual effect is not a point of discussion really. Everyone has been referencing too Unlimited Money Works anyway. Colorful, eye-catching visual effect and high octane fights with huge frame rate are not something you should be surprised about anymore. I admit when I see them used in Kara no Kyoukai I was blown away but by now I feel kind of over it by now. I would tell you what it lacks though: art direction. Art is not really about looking life like and stuffs, it is about leaving an impression on the observer. In this case since they used up too much money on fight scenes they forgot about the dull conversations one that are as boring as you might imagine. Of course in its defense talks are often happening inside Shirou house, a place that has nothing striking at all about it. I already had this problem with ufotable since Kara no Kyoukai but forgive it because it was fresh and the dark tone was well used combining with the lighting. I vividly remembers how unimpressed the river fight in fate zero was and now unlimited blade works reminded me of that. \n
The sound is another disappointment. DEEN might not be the best when it comes to, well anything really but the old Fate soundtrack was, let's face it, really really good. Moody atmospheric and mysterious, it almost saves that atrocious adaption. This one doesn't spin me the way the old one did, something I have noticed after Kara no Kyoukai left me with only one track that I really like. I guess Ufotable strength isn't in the music. The sound of magic and weapons are so so I guess, I can't really make comments about things I have no idea about. \n
If I have to admit I did enjoy watching my favorite route making an appearance full length and seeing the heart scene and the dual scene brings back all the memory of my youth. However my mind keep nagging my nostalgia gut about being level headed and stuffs and regretfully I have to tell those who really like Fate Stay Night series that this one isn't bringing anything new to the table and not worth your time. If you like to start this series this one isn't really good as well because unfortunately the layout of the visual novel is actually the best to expose this storyline: Fate set up the basic concept and knowledge about this world, unlimited blade works explore the main character moral in greater detail and heavenly feels flip all the stones over. Starting the series on this one is ok I guess but the full package really comes as I have said.  If you like some cool action stuffs like Attack on Titans UBW TV barely makes it because the gore and death was the fun part of Shingeki no Kyoujin as frankly with a risk the action wouldn't be half as fun. Fate series has always been about character and world building so action fans won't be fully satisfy here. \n
That begs the question to me, what was the point of making this one?\n
To please the fan? As a fan I think it pretty much flopped. \n
To jump start newcomers? The story of this one is kind of convoluted compares to Fate route.\n
My guess is to capitalize on the Fate Zero hype. The thing is though Fate Zero great character, good dialogue, great storyline, good plot, decent writing (from the fact that a writer wrote them of course) and enough emphasis on action and tension is what made Fate Zero great. UBW doesn't have any of that stuffs. Fate Zero is a whole meal while UBW is a part of a 3 course dinner. It cannot be done the same way. \n
I do recommend trying to one out if you have not watched a Fate entry. \n\n
Beyond the show\n
If I have to give Ufotable one advice that would be finding a writer right now. Their show writing has always been a pillar to their show. Kara no Kyoukai blows the short movie scene with rich art, good writing and the same was made to TV show by Fate Zero. In all honestly the Japanese sucks at writing dialogues but are masters at overreaching plot. Seriously, Kojima dialogues are long and excruciating but its synopsis made me did the stupid thing of playing through the whole series many years ago when its entries are still countable with one hand (exclude the ones without the solid). Conversation writing is hard but it has been done well before and there is no reason the Japanese studio can't do it again. Bones with director Tensai did a good job on Darker than Black and older ones like Ghost in the Shell or Cowboy Bebop have proven that the Japanese has more than enough capability to bridge this gap. \n
I also want to comment on why recent Japanese games are so shit in terms of story (specifically FF series). It used to not be voiced and the writing was all we could read. The voicing ended up making their dialogues slower (due to us having to listen) and at the same time taking away the joy of imagining these voices. Chrono Trigger and FF6 with voice would be disastrous after I try playing them and talk about every piece of dialogues. Their story might retain the grandeur of old but the charm has been squashed out. FF series is even worse because all of their focus is on the shitty graphic that one honestly cares about. This is why the Fate Visual Novel for me is better even though the show is basically moving the dialogue in the game to the show. Still, Japan needs to learn more about dialogue or at least shorten them, telling them "Dark Souls style" that is so quintessentially Japanese that makes them so great and adored.

Fate/ Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works based on the visual novel by type moon. Directed by Kenichi Takeshita. I couldnt watch more than 2 eps of the first fate stay night it just didnt trap me. . . ye. F/SN:UBW i guess the reboot, kicked ass. Action, animation, characters were all done way better of course this is my opinion. 
The plot essence isn't exactly new but its interesting. So the holy grail war is whats happening and its happened before. 7 mages get a servant each and these servant are hero's of old coming back to fight once more. The grail is whats beingsought after and when obtained a wish can be granted. 


What was done right, the fact that its not always from Emiyas point of view (this dude is way . . . stubborn) In the beggining i was scoffing, hissing and tutting at almost everything he had to say but thanks to Rin and her point of view it wasnt to much. (you get why hes like that later on and its satisfying).

          The action was epic i could rewatch most of the sequences and enjoy them just as much as the first time. The mains arent OP so you see some real development of skills. 

         The mood of this anime is kinda dark, and i guess serious with few light parts. The things i took away from the anime is one of the biggest credits i can give i feel like i have to wait a bit after some episodes and just meditate on it alil, even though i feel like they can go into somethings more i was pretty happy thinkin on it on my own.


Not many negatives except for a minor distaste for Emiya at points. I thought it could have been longer, talking about the other mages and heros a bit more but for what was given satisfied is an understatement. 


Do i recommend this? Hell to the yes. Its well done and visually, its unique in ways that really add to the enjoyment. I rate this Badass

(This is a review for both seasons.)
Story: 7/10 	
 	Fate Stay/Night Unlimited Blade Works is the sequel to Fate/Zero and is the alternative version of Fate Stay/Night. It revolves the fifth war for the holy grail with seven masters and seven servants duking it out for the ultimate reward, which grants anyone wish. This wasn’t my introduction to the Fate universe since previously I watched the critically acclaimed prequel Fate/Zero which could be comparable to Anime’s Game of Thrones. Gen Urobuchi had a perfectly paced, and extremely interesting cast of characters with Fate/Zero, and after the stellar second season I craved more Fate, especially Rinwho I was really glad to find out is the main female lead of UBW. If you’ve seen any Fate adaptation the basic story structure seems to be the same, but what changes with each series of films is the revolving door of characters and all the different clashing ideologies that come to a head in beautifully animated action scenes or just discussions between masters and/or servants. The actual structure of the story is a bit cliche so the action scenes and relationship building between characters really added a bit of spice and substance to the overall plot, but it still isn’t anything exemplary.


Characters: 8/10


Shirou Emiya-


	It should go without saying but major spoilers for Fate/Zero will come up during this review, to explain character motivations and backstories. Shirou was rescued from an expansive fire by Kiritsugu after he forced for Saber to destroy the Holy Grail. He has always admired heroes of justice and always admired his adopted dad Kiritsugu. He vows to become the hero that Kiritsugu couldn’t due to his old age, and it really sucks that Kiritsugu kicks the bucket before this series started since he was definitely one of the best characters in Zero. Anyways Shirou always puts others lives above his own which seems good in theory but is actually very impractical and he ever acknowledges how childish is ideologies can be but he still finds his aspirations to be too pure and good for his hypocrisy to get to him. Still he really does have the best of intentions and is probably one of the best teammates or allies that you could have, due to his tenacity and projection skills. His way of looking at things seem to match up very well with Saber’s so it made sense that they got along very well throughout the series. Due to this you can’t ever hate him, but it’s possible that is ideologies and his persistence with them can get on your nerves.


Rin Toosaka-


 	She showed a ton of promise when I first watched her as a child in Zero, and she somewhat lived up to my expectations for UBW. She’s extremely competent, sarcastic, and well meaning. She is the expert and was raised to become a master in the war for the Holy Grail. She is a bit of a tsundere considering she is pretty stern, proper, and easily agitated on the outside, but on the inside she’s a big softie. She thinks very practically, the opposite of Shiro who’s is impulsive as hell. Also I just love her voice in this dub, and her voice also stuck out in particular for me with Zero. The only thing that I thought was done a bit poorly was her relationship with Shirou. The pacing of it didn't feel natural at all to me, and that they just had them get together in the end/epilogue to tie everything in a nice little bow. Like it makes sense for Shirou, but when didn’t she have such a change of heart considering how lovey dovey she seemed with Shirou in the Epilogue. Again, besides that she is golden.


Saber-


 	She’s the heroic spirit summoned by Shirou, and she was King Arthur. She is really strong, and well meaning. She seems to share the same heroic aspirations as Shirou, though she regrets how her past went down, and if she had the holy grail that would have been the one thing that she would change. She character seemed quite a bit different in UBW compared to Zero, since she always seemed more doubting and untrusting compared to how she acts in UBW. She seemed to trust Shirou a lot more even though he is a pretty incompetent mage at the beginning, like she seemed too carefree when she was summoned, like her character was altered slightly. This might just be a nitpick, but it was eating at me a little bit while I was watching UBW. Still she is has a ton of chivalrous badass moments, that any little flaws in her character’s consistency can be overlooked. 


Animation/Art Style: 10/10


	Ufotable have done an incredible job with all their entries in the fate series in the visual department. The animation and artstyle of UBW are motion picture quality, everything just looks so crisp and beautiful, that you could stare at still frames for hours just to bask in the magnificence of it all. The action scenes are very fluid and high in intensity. I have no qualms with anything visually, I even love how most of the characters look. 


Sound: 8/10


	The soundtrack is filled to the brim with orchestral pieces, which get you pumped for the eye candy to come. The scale of the soundtrack is grand, with many pieces fitting the mood to a tee, though most of it is supplementary and can’t really stand on its own, unless you have a large hankering for some orchestral music. There are some more exotic pieces too, which gives off a mysterious and calming vibe. Both openings look gorgeous and sound good, but I for the life of me can’t remember how either of them go, so overall they are enjoyable but not quality enough to stick with you after the fact.


Enjoyment: 8/10


	Some of this may have sounded harsh, but I still did enjoy UBW quite a lot. The action and animation are top notch, and I love a couple characters in  the main cast. But UBW has a couple things going against it. 1. The plot still isn’t anything to write home about, and even some of the solid writing can’t save it, and 2. the second half falters quite a bit when it nears its end. Nothing in this series struck a chord with me like Zero did, but if you want learn more about this interesting universe, and just want to have a fun and enjoyable time then definitely check this series out. I would say start with Zero then watch this (though I haven’t seen the 2006 alternative version, and do really have any plans of doing so in the future).

I watched this entire series over the weekend.  "Why wasn't I watching this earlier?"  is my only question. 
Story(8/10) 
UBW has a few key differences to FSN in terms of who the story focuses on. It had an episode zero which focused entirely on Rin Tohsaka  the female main character of this series. The story tends to give more focus on Rin and Archer than its predecessor FSN did.  Since this is based on the visual novel UBW follows the true ending to the Unlimited Blade Works arc. I feel Unlimited Blade works universe set one of the darker precedents inthe Fate Stay universe and the plot often reflects this tone. \n
Art (9/10) \n
This is partially what made me quit Fate Stay Night and kept me watching UBW. The art is gorgeous in this series. When it isn't a thrilling  action scene, it's a stunning background showing a colorful landscape. I really love the landscape shots in this series and how they bring life to the characters in this show. \n
Sound(9/10) \n
Most of the OST is great. I did watch the OP and ED the first time but skipped it subsequent times. The VAs on this show are also very good.  I can't think of a Japanese VA that wasn't originally from Fate Stay Night.  Due to there being more Archer in this series, you can tell the work Junichi Suwabe put into his lines and delivery. He plays the perfect manipulative jerk. \n
Character (8/10) \n
I only give this an eight out of 10 because I hate Shinji and they focused less on Sakura. Although it detracted from the focus on Saber, I felt that the focus on Tohsaka, and Archer and their relationship to Shirou was a very good thing in terms of character development. I didn't like Shirou at first as the main protagonist. Good selfless characters feel dull to me. This show did a good job of averting this and even addressing the problems with such a character. Shirou's flaws felt well portrayed. As for the 8/10, this might be a minor gripe, but out of two siblings Sakura and Shinji, they decided to focus more on the one I can't stand.  There are characters who are jerks in this show(i.e Archer, Gilgamesh) , but I felt like Shinji had no fleshing out character wise. He was just a borderline-rapist coward slime and every scene he lived was an irritating one.  \n
Enjoyment(10/10) \n
Just the general environment of this show appeals to me. The action was amazing and I loved the OST . The characters were interesting and enjoyable(exception Shinji). I was hooked by the plot. In conclusion, I would recommend giving this show a watch.

In a world where Masters fight for the Holy Grail, a novice mage is thrown into the mix. Fate brings to my plate something that I can't really explain, but it threw me in for a ride.
Story: Fate starts off with the premise of what is basically a magical girl anime (y'know, with the whole having an aptitude for something), but then retracts that claim in order to set up what I think is a solid story. The events all match up and are timed so that you aren't overwhelmed but also aren't bored. You get your relationship building, your backstories, and your action allin one large, but manageable package. I felt that the build ups were done well too, and tension before something was done skillfully.


Art: Besides the obvious fact that this was done by ufotable, and thus should obviously come out as having amazing art, I'll give my opinions on it. Art was, as stated, really good. Transitions and animations were smooth, and scenes with magic really stand out. Fight scenes are also animated well, even having some "3D" sections that look great. Expressions on the characters are also really well drawn, and the mood of any scene is so noticeable that I bet someone without any prior knowledge could walk in the room and immediately understand what is going on. 


Sound: Voice acting in Fate was like what I normally review for other animes, but it goes the extra mile with the battle scenes. Fate's voice acting in battle scenes are what I believe to be the highlight when it comes to their VAs. Sure, it's limited to one emotion, but that is conveyed the best when compared to the other scenes. Even so, really emotional scenes are still really well voice acted, and you can still get a kick out of those. But enough of that, now onto the main event: the music. Fate has some of the best background music of any anime that I've watched so far, and that's really something. The music prepares you for battle, puts you into the battle, and also intensifies the mood overall of the scenes. Even the opening is something to be noted, as that eases you into whatever the episode is going to be, whether a casual and less action packed episode, or one that's filled with just that. The ED is a bit more tame, but still does a great job of easing the viewer out of an episode. Overall, sound was done extremely well.


Character: Alright, here's where the anime suffers just a bit. It's not like I don't like the characters, but I think that they could have been done better. Emiya is portrayed as a defender of justice, whose ideals prevent him from seeing the bigger picture, and ultimately are the cause for most of his downfalls. He's not a bad protag, but I just wanted to see him change, and maybe become more like Archer, you know? Anyways, onto Rin. Rin is our series staple tsundere, but I feel that she was done a bit better. Rin's overall character feels a bit stuck up, but I will say that it fits her character. She's not exactly unlikeable, but it is a bit hard to like her at first. She, and like Emiya, take a bit of time to adjust to, but they end up being alright in the end. Now, Archer. Archer was, in my opinion, the best character in this season. He starts off as a mysterious and also cocky man, but in time is shown to act his way due to what he has to experience. He's relatable, and also uses his cockiness and sarcastic personality in moderation, making him not annoying. Archer also comes off as basically Emiya if he was a bit more experienced in life, and were to know that you can't save everyone. Besides the fact I do know who all the servants are, I can put myself in the place of someone who doesn't and still know that Archer is someone that should be noted.


Enjoyment: I enjoyed this anime very much, if you couldn't tell. Actually, so much, that I binged 10 episodes in one day. I'll get more into specifics in the Overall portion.


Overall: My thoughts overall on this series is that it was solid. It had amazing sound and visuals, but also had a story that was pleasing to follow. The only thing that could be improved on in my opinion was character, but this show did it in a way that even character wasn't that bad. In the end, everything was how I wanted it to be, and was enjoyable to the end. If you've not watched this yet, but have watched any other Fate series, I highly recommend UBW.

The intention of this review is to cover the series as a whole, including the 2nd season. The Fate series are quite famous and not in need of much introduction. If you are reading this, you probably have already some experience with them. (Note that I mainly rate based on enjoyment and my opinions are subjective to my personal tastes and kindness).  
Story
The storyline is an alternative course of events to the previous anime Fate/stay night from the 2006. During the first few episodes, the events are the same with the 2006 version, but then the characters start to make different decisions which leadto different events. The story flowed quite nicely and I was always left with anticipation for the next episode. Towards the last episodes though, I did get the feeling that some parts were dragged much longer in duration than necessary as if the creators did not have other material to fill the required episodes. However, it wasn't that bad and it didn't affect the overall flow. With that said, it doesn't mean that there aren't a couple of things here and there that do not reasonably match with the expected result. However, I am keeping my reservations on that matter as humans are always unpredictable :P  There was also a point to the story that everyone had realised a specific secret about one of the characters (including the audience), but it took several episodes to come out in the open, which somehow stole a bit of the element of surprise regarding the plot shift. I did feel some dissatisfaction that certain characters did not learn few truths about the others, but I suppose that this was how things were to end up in this timeline. In terms of action, it surely had very well directed and memorable battle scenes. These complimented well the story and the conflicts between the characters. 


Art

In terms of the graphic art, I consider the anime of very high quality. The colours, the details of the scenes, and the animation are all very carefully and elegantly designed. But, surely that is something to be expected by the ufotable studio (of which I confess I am a fan, so maybe there is some bias there). The art and colours definitely fit the fantasy theme of the series and made it memorable and lively. The designs of the characters resemble the 2006 version but are more detailed and more appealing. Yet, you can still relate them to their previous versions. 


Sound

The voices of the characters were the same as the 2006 version, as well as the Fate/Zero anime. I personally believe that the voices fit the characters personality and it's nice to have this sort of consistency through the different series. The soundtrack was also really good. Especially the chores accompanying the battle scenes were giving off that epic feeling that is expected in such moments. There are a few tracks from the soundtrack that have made it into my music playlists. I did not find the opening and ending songs of both seasons memorable or stuck in my head, but there are nice tracks and fit the anime's aura. 


Character

A great deal of the series revolves around Shirou's desire/dream. This desire/dream can be considered either as a flaw or a strength, and through the story the audience is given arguments for both sides. In general, I believe that all the characters explained well their actions and the reasons for which they took a specific side over another. The arguments are well rounded and really important in order to understand the characters' personality. There were a couple of times that I felt that some characters were presented too clever or knowledgeable despite their age for the sake of progressing the plot. But I easily overlooked that part. On a side note, I find Gilgamesh, one of the main antagonists, as one of the most interesting personalities I have come across despite of his rotten side (or maybe because of that). Either way, he is a bonus to the show (and of course the actor who is voicing him - I absolutely love it). 


Enjoyment

I confess that in terms of satisfaction, I was expecting something similar with the Fate/Zero. The creators tried to do so, but it didn't get as far. Of course, the series were very enjoyable and thought provoking.  In the future, I would definitely like to re-watch the parts of the series where the most interesting arguments and impressive battles happened. To conclude, I would recommend this anime whether you are a fan of the franchise or not.

Okay, heads up, I will be vaguely comparing this work to the original 2006 anime. So, there maybe a few slight spoilers here and there. Nothing that will ruin your own watchthrough, though.
So, I was under the impression that UBW would be essentially a remake of the 2006 series except from Rin's POV instead of Shirou's. That isn't the case, though. If I understand correctly, the three routes (Fate, UBW, Heaven's Feel) serve to simply hook Shirou up with Saber, Rin, and Sakura respectively. Naturally, who he falls for affects the story, so there are some differences in how things go down. Also, the originalanime heavily focused on Saber as the main Servant, giving us her backstory, etc. while UBW focuses on Archer and his origins. 


Anyway, with those logistics out of the way, I'll say that I really enjoyed this first season. I recommend watching the 2006 anime as well because it's quite fun to see where the two diverge vs. where they're the same. I do think I prefer the Fate route to the UBW route (so far, anyway, I haven't watching the second season, obviously). I found the story between Saber and Shirou so magical, but I also love learning more about Rin in this route so I still have a lot of love for UBW.


Anyway, yeah, that's it. Solid first season. Solid story.

Another day, another review I write about an Anime that has been covered to death. But, seeing as "Fate/Zero" is my favorite Anime series this one is mandatory. "Fate/stay night: Unlimited Blade Works" is an unusual series due to the fact it's a re-make of a series that "Fate/Zero" was the prequel to, making this more of a sequel than an original work. But, seeing how "Fate/Zero" was superior to it's predecessor in every way one would grant the creators a chance to go back in order to go forward. Confused yet? Me, too. Anyway, on to the meat of the review.
Fantasy/Action Anime doesn't getmuch better than this series overall. The story is a strong one, with many good characters, twists, turns, and exciting action. It loses a point or two from me because it takes a lot of the time in a high school, with half the cast comprised of students and teachers. I swear if Anime had a Toon Town it would be one, giant high school. But, I digress. The artwork is very good, enriched with CG effects and great sound, and provides some gorgeous battle sequences and unique characters that take part in them. This is by far the strongest part of Season 1 and kudos to the writers for picking a great spot for a mid-series break. \n\n
The Sub vs. Dub battle is one of the closest I've had to judge in a long time, and I honestly prefer the English Dub a bit more than the Japanese. You can't go wrong with either, tho. The difficult part of this review is that it's only for the first half of the series. And it's very good, it has it's slow points while it throws exposition at you, but it gives you a great ride and sets itself up for a thrilling conclusion. Overall, I wouldn't put this series quite on the level of "Fate/Zero" but it holds up very well. 8/10. Look forward to Season 2. Check it out.

After watching the main Anime adaptations of the Fate series I must say that I'm very glad to have experienced this series. Episode after episode I get more interested and attached to Fate and because of good reason.
What I love about Fate is actually that it contains everything of what one would want to see in a series. 
From a serious, outstanding story to average slice of life elements and even romance. And Fate manages to balance all of these elements without failure in my opinion. 
So far I've only seen the Anime adaptations but after this almost overwhelming marathon I'm absolutely ready to readthe original visual novel and I'm definitely excited of what the original story will deliver.


As for this review:


Story: Fate/Stay Night Unlimited Blade Works adapts the second route of the original visual novel (from what I've read) pretty faithfully. The story will surely make you think thoroughly about your own self and everyone who watched the Anime will exactly know what I mean....

One of the most maturely narrated stories I've ever seen.


Art: Oh, god the animation...Words can't describe how gorgeous it is. Seriously, I can't say anything more to this section because I'm absolutely in awe with it.


Sound: Beautiful openings and endings. Every single one was remarkable and I think you won't be disappointed with the mesmerizing artist that is called Aimer.


Character: Well, admittedly I do have some issues with the main character but his personality is unusal and unique so I can't argue about that. In fact, actually no one in Fate is predictable or straight up stereotypical, another strong point in the series and I think everyone will eventually find his own, personal favourite.


Enjoyment: I instantly got hooked, the excitement I felt was incredible and I enjoyed the hell out of it. This goes for the whole series respectfully.


Overall: I honestly think that we need more stories like these, stories who will provoke thought, who will make us question about our own philosophy and lastly about humanity itself. If we don't question our own lives and ideals then we will always be stuck in a repeated circle of a monochrome mindset. That's how I'm interpreting this story and it's huge message for everyone. 

But of course not everyone can think of it like that so watch the Anime and then make up your own opinion. Whether you'll like it or not is completely up to you but I think you won't get disappointed.

Let me sing my praises to UFOTABLE - for managing to perfectly adapt the Fate/Stay Night: Unlimited Blade Works visual novel (VN) into a two-season anime series! The GLORIOUS artwork, animation and soundtracks easily put it among my top 3 favorite anime series in this decade!
My favorite character is Archer: the unique design, the calmness, the no-nonsense attitude, the sarcasm, cynicism, assessments of others, and even "old-man talk" (haha). I love every fight that Archer engages in in this anime. Even though he's not a 5-star Servant in terms of power, he manages to pull win after win against tough opponents by utilizing tactics --He's a symbol of "trying your best".


I must say, watching Ufotable's adaptation is much more satisfying than reading the VN, because I get to see the most fantastic, epic, eye-pleasing battles that one can ever see in the anime world. I also get to see the characters' movements and interactions - which I can only imagine in my head when reading the VN. I also am extremely pleased to see that Ufotable's adaptation stay faithful to the original VN work! Although all internal monologues are cut out, the anime - through its amazing animation - successfully conveys all the subtleties in the ways the characters interact and fight.


There is no other company that I would entrust this franchise to. I am looking forward to Ufotable's adaption of Fate/Stay Night: Heaven's Feel. I also hope that they will adapt Fate/Hollow Ataraxia soon!


My favorite OST is EMIYA theme ! Absolutely epic!

Welcome you lovely Otaku brothers and sisters of mine,and welcome to my first anime review on this site. Now today we are gonna be tackling, Fate/stay night: Unlimited blade works. Specifically the first season in this review, I will rate the second season and make  a review as well. Though for now lets just discuss the first half of...
what I believe to be one of the best looking anime that I have ever seen, in most anime the production studio will emphasize the quality of some scenes over other scenes. This leaves you with a final product that looks well, distorted in a weirdway. It's not that the animation is bad, but the animation either doesn't feel fluid in scenes with just exposition and dialogue or some scenes feel alienated from others because of the difference in animation. Let me tell you that with this anime that sure as hell isn't the case with this, each scene is animated to look amazing whether it's exposition or another on off Fates amazing action sequences. Not only showcasing it's huge budget, but its amazing team. The writing characters are also just so well written and feel so real each given a motivation instead of forcing conflict. All in all after looking back over this anime I give this anime a nine out of ten, the only thing stopping me from giving this anime a ten out of ten are the some small nit picks. Though this anime is a must see, I would have to say you should watch the original Fate/stay night. I hope this review helped your decision on watching this anime, and tell me what anime  you want me to review in the future. Have a great day my otaku friends

***talks about season 2 as well"""
First things first, if you walk into this show expecting a masterpiece similar to Fate/Zero, you'll need to reevaluate your expectations. This show is by no means a bad show; in fact, it's probably better than most of the anime out there. But as a Zero sequel, it falls flat. This is the inevitable problem of adapting a VN, since an anime on a single route leaves out so much and never feels quite complete. Ufotable did the best it could with what it was given, but the show couldn't meet the standard Zero set.
What went wrong? Naturally, when adaptinga VN to anime, you'll need to cut out ALOT of details. The visual novel was essentially alot of cooking, eroge scenes and story, and I'm glad Ufotable got rid of the former two. They could have, however, focused on fleshing out the major points of the story well, as this is where the problem starts. Shirou, the protagonist of the series, is never given any depth or good backstory; we simply get a few PTSD flashbacks that show us he had a hard time in his past, but we are never given insight into his mind. So, whenever he does something stupid (which is 100% of the time), you can't help but hate him and ask why he's so irrational. And since he's the focus of the show, he just brings the story down. Besides him, the other characters are actually interesting, and it's a shame they weren't fleshed out at the expense of Shirou. \n\n
The redeeming qualities of this show are definitely Archer and Gilgamesh. Archer combats Shirou's stupidity with actual rational thought and complex backstory, and Gilgamesh is a good villain like always. Unfortunately, the series does not provide any closure for alot of the things left open-ended in Fate/Zero (Kirei reviving the Grail and settling his dispute with the Emiyas/Matous, Saber redeeming herself, etc).

I can describe this anime in a few ways but I say this was just an epic anime. I can now say I am a fan of this series and am excited for Season 2. 
Story: Fate/Stay night centers around the holy grail war, that all I can basically say to tried to avoid spoilers. The story I would give a 8. 
Art: The animation is a really step up from the original series (even though I personally have not watched it). The animation felt realistic and just so beautiful. The art I would give a 10. 
Sound: Personally I watched the sub for thisanime, I listened to the dub for like a second but I was like I prefer the Sub on this. The actors did the role right and it was fantastic. The sound 'I give a 7. \n\n
Characters: Rin: Great female character for the anime. Archer: Handsome but very cool. Shirou: He is the character though the viewers eyes is the learning person of the world. Saber: Badass that all I say. The characters I give an 8. \n\n
Enjoyment and overall/ rewatch recommendation: Through my ride I loved this anime, and I am looking forward to watching season 2. My rewatch value is a 10. My personal enjoyment is a 9, and my overall value is also a 9.
