«The one who obtains the Holy Grail will have any wish come true. »
The story of the Holy Grail is a well-known legend that already inspired numerous movies and books. Therefore, having an anime on this subject is not surprising, but it’s still an intriguing mixture of cultures. In 2004, the Japanese game company Type-Moon released the visual novel “Fate/stay night”, a very long game including 3 different versions (routes) of one story. The release was a huge success, and rapidly secured the title of the highest selling visual novel in 2004. Consequently, a lot of adaptions followed: manga, anime, light novels, video games…
Fate: UnlimitedBlade Works (UBW) is the adaptation of the second route of the original game, I highly recommend watching Fate/Stay night and Fate/Zero before UBW. Since it’s another version of the same story, the story alone is understandable for the Fate neophyte but there will be references that you will not get.


The story takes place in the city of Fuyuki, Emiya Shirou is a normal hardworking student, with the exception of his heavy past: his parents died in a fire when he was a kid and he was saved by a man called Kiritsugu Emiya, which is no longer of this world. These events cause Shirou to be a very altruistic person, helping others even when it’s at his expense.


After staying late at school to clean the archery dojo, Shirou stumbles upon a battle between two magical beings called Servants. Servants are the reincarnation of heroes of all time, superhuman warriors fighting in the Holy Grail War under the command of 7 Master, sorcerers seeking the Grail. Of course Shirou didn’t know any of that when witnessing the scene and is quickly spotted despite trying to stay hidden. One of the two servants, for the sake of the secrecy of the war, goes after Shirou and pierce his heart with a spear. But Shirou didn’t die that night, his life was saved by an unknown person and he finds himself unwillingly carried in a secret war between magi.


This story is sublimated by the best animation I’ve seen for an anime TV series: everything is full of details, the scenery is a spectacle even in the most banal scenes, the movements are fluid and natural and the fight scenes incredibly rich.


Concerning the sound, the voice acting doesn’t fail the iconic characters and the music has some really good themes and even after finishing the show I like listening to the OST of UBW.


I’ve been told several times that 10 is maybe a little high for this anime, but Unlimited Blade Works really matched my expectations for the second route of the Visual novel.

I write this for both seasons. After seeing Fate/stay night (FSN), I could immediately tell that in terms of quality, this was made better. I liked FSN better, but this would appeal to critics more. Why?
The plotline is more logical than that of FSN, for one thing. The events are more combat-based, which I of course enjoyed, and Shirou is not so focused on Saber. (Although that was precisely why I loved FSN.) The art, again, is awesome, and the fight scenes are magnificent. One of the facets to the enormous diamond of anime is that the fight scenes are so fast to the humaneye and that characters are wickedly good at fighting. In comparison to FSN, Unlimited Blade Works (UBW) was also more focused on Shirou's realization of his ideals. To fight for others, regardless of the consequences. To summon weapons from nothing but his mind, continuously too. One of the best anime titles, too. Take an anime like FMAB or Code Geass. The titles are apt, yes, but nothing extraordinary. Take the Fate/stay night series. Most creative titles I know so far, since you can't really tell what they mean. You can guess. Bleach is interesting, I'm on episode 19 and I'm still pondering...\n\n
Pardon the digression. The art is brilliant. The sound, like that of FSN, is great, but less emotional and more driven. The character is less focused on Saber and more focused on Saber and Rin. Rin, I have to say, is a strong character. Not very attractive in my opinion in the UBW version (FSN is better), but nevertheless a good tsundere. The characterization of Shirou Emiya and his quest to discover who he is -- now that is what drives this anime. After all, all stories are delineated by setting and driven by characters, who manifest the plot. If you want to see good fight scenes, strong characters, and AWESOME opening themes -- I mean, Ideal White and Brave Shine (also good titles) are two of my favorites. Not only are the vocals awesome but the action within the opening is good, too. If an opening is really good, that means the creators of the particular anime were motivated to do so, which means the anime itself is worthy of watching.

Having watched fate/zero first, I had huge expectations for stay night: UBW but they were surpassed by the prologue episode before the main show. Let's start the review!
Story:
This is quite a unique story. 7 mages and their respective servants fighting to the death for the omnipotent holy grail. Expect alliances to be formed and broken as characters will do anything to gain the upper hand. This is where the amazing plot twists and turns arise and provide an amazing narrative with never a dull moment in sight.
Art:
We all know the fate series is famous for its stylistic fighting/action sequences and this is no exception. UBWdepicts each battle perfectly and shows the anime world how CGI should be used.\n\n
Character:\n
All characters were well developed, played a pivotal roll in the storyline and offered something new to the series.\n\n
Overall:\n
I consider this to be the best anime I have ever seen and highly recommend it!!!\n
10/10\n

Fate/Zero was amazing, but does Ufotable bring justice to the original deal. Absolutely! Though, it isn't quite as polished.
As per usual with Ufotable Fate productions, the animation and soundtrack are amazing. I can even look over the fact that they use the stock metal clanging sound that Garry's Mod uses (to be frank, who doesn't use them?) because the anime looks and sounds so breathtaking.
That being said, the story, I'm afraid, doesn't have the polish that is present in Zero. It likes to add a lot of SOL elements that, while being faithful to the novel, drags the plot to a halt at many points.Also, the characters are great, but their motivations are not convincing sometimes. For instance, Shirou wants to be a hero of justice, but the how and why are kind of vague. Rin wants to protect Shirou, but it's never really defined why. A lifedebt? love? They for the most part are clearer near the end, but can be irritating to sit through early. That said, Shirou and Rin do go through a healthy deal of character development that helps the watcher feel more attached to them. Though, it can't be said for other otherwise great characters, like Rin and especially Illya (I haven't even seem Prisma Illya and I'm already in love with her character, but not in a Chris Hansen Way. Also for the record, she's 18-19). 


Back to topic, Ufotable makes up for the less substance with even more style. Big explosions that would make Michael Bay jealous, and lightshows galore. The battles are not quite as intelligent or calculated as Zero, but are intensely great in a Dragon Ball or Pretty Cure way as in lots of contact, great animation, and lots of crap thrown around.  


The dub is pretty good. I didn't watch the sub yet, will probably try that next time. Mela Lee as Rin sounds kinda scratchy but gets the flustered teen right. Shirou sounds like your typical shounen protagonist, but then again, he kinda is (at least in UBW). David Vincent as Gilgamesh and Crispin Freeman as Kirei, as usual is deviously great. Kari Wahlgren also nails Saber yet again.


So, to conclude it isn't as good as Zero, but it had pretty big shoes to fill, and I think it filled them pretty good. 


RECOMMENDATION: HIGH


PS: I would like to point out, if you are a newcomer, you shouldn't start the with this one, since it retroactively spoils much of Fate/Zero since it was made in part with it in mind, and as such many plot points from it are mentioned. 


There are three good options


1. Watch Fate/Zero, if you can't get the visual novel and don't want to watch the Deen adaptation.


2. Read the VN and then watch Zero.


3. Watch the serviceable (so I'm told) 2006 Deen adaptation that focuses on the Fate route.


Zero was written with Stay Night in mind so it's preferable to watch either the 2006 anime or read the novel first if you managed to know this fact, which I didn't unfortunately,  but don't watch this before Zero.

What can I say about the Fate series other than its good.Like its really not a lie it really is that good as they say.Nowhere else will you find a series that can compete in terms of complexity and lore.The show has legends from all of time.Imagine how long will it take to read all of them.Easily over hundreds of heroes are featured in total but only seven are chosen to be part of this particular show.
Now onto the story.Now this is just my opinion but this route the UBW route is my personal favorite from the 3 routes due to the dept of thestory.The questioning of ones ideals and the overcoming of those walls set by those who say that your ideals will never be realised or your ideals are only going to give you nothing but pain.This is the story of Emiya Shirou and quite frankly no one else's.

Fate/Stay Night Unlimited Blade works is 10 years after the events of Fate/Zero, and just there things start to be very interesting.
Through the story of UBW are we shown a lot of hints and things from Zero, which I just love as it makes it feel more real and in connection between the two stories.
What to say though is UBW lighter in the mood than Zero, that was most of the time very dark and grim. While there is lots of it in UBW as well, does it have some lighthearted moments to break up all the dark things going on.
Ufotable definitely doesn't hold back,cause the animations in UBW is simply outstanding. The battles are crazy amazing, by epic proportions. This composed with great music and sounds make it even greater. 


Characters have a great mix of interesting ones, all from Servants to Masters. Shirou is a very odd and different one, as he live for his extreme ideals, as he try to survive the chaos he been thrown into.

Rin is moody and have a switching temper! Though consider previous events am I not surprised if she have lot's of suppressed memories and she takes it out with her mood.

But in general do I think the characters are very good and interesting, some more than others!


Through and through, did I really enjoy this anime for it's outstanding animation, interesting characters and simply well composited. Though as usual can it be hard where to start with the Fate series, but oh well. xD


For me was the show very emotional and gripping at times, not as powerful as Zero, but definitely up there and is a great anime either you like action, well animation or Fate in general. I think it's worth a watch!


And my reaction to the entire show https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLFiDOren6dOULFaYDUYJqBgF4_AFocW7_ I'm still amazed by the beauty of this anime!

Nine years after the release of the original Fate/Stay Night, here I find myself writing a review for none other but Fate/Stay Night. However, this is not just another repeat/summary but rather a completely different route, and one that brings FSN into alignment with the events of Fate/Zero. For those who have watched the original FSN, the beginning may seem familiar but soon the divergence becomes strikingly apparent. For those who have watched the FSN UBW movie, this is a much more thorough version of that movie (unfortunately, you will know most of the large plot twists already). For those who have watched Fate/Zero, you'llfinally get your contiguous story line. If you have been in a vacuum and not seen any Type Moon works of the FSN series, I recommend starting with Fate/Zero.


This review encompasses both seasons of this latest iteration of FSN and will use Fate/Zero as a standard for comparison (and will assume that you have watched it). Oh, and most importantly, this is the Tousaka route (the original FSN featured Saber's route and the upcoming movie FSN Heaven's Feel will showcase Sakura's route); Tousaka addicts rejoice, this show overflows with Kana Ueda's spot on tsundere performance.


So how does the latest FSN stack up? The production values are right up there with Fate/Zero and the story is pretty much an extended version of the UBW movie. I do feel that some characters had a much diminished role as compared to the original FSN, and overall it isn't as dark (and male-voice dominated) as Fate/Zero. Nonetheless, this still ranks as a must see; it truly sets the bar for what you can get for what ApexE aptly terms "Unlimited Budget Works". Moreover, if you happen to be a Tousaka fan, this is an absolute no brainer.


If you're so inclined as to pick up this show, do note that there is a special episode 0 (Rin's version of episode 1 really) and episode 25 (epilogue that tidies things up nicely).


Animation:

The overall animation is absolute eye candy. The list of outstanding qualities in this show was so long that I literally had to jot notes to keep track of what I liked. To start, the colorization is very well done, and is at the very least on par with Fate/Zero. One of the best animated sunsets I've ever seen was in Fate/Zero; they must have heard me or something as they once again do an amazing transition, this time at the very end of the epilogue. Backgrounds are in general sharp and well drawn; I particularly liked the nighttime cityscapes. As with Fate/Zero, expect the color palette to create a dark, somewhat menacing atmosphere- the show definitely feels a bit darker than the original FSN.


There were some rough edges in the production, however. The show has some of the best looking CGI-generated water that I've ever seen, yet also has some of the most mechanical-looking walking students that I've witnessed. Character-wise, all the characters from FSN return though with differing importance from the original- there's a lot less of Sakura, Ilya, and Saber than in the original (though Saber's behavior here fits more with her performance from F/Z). What particularly stood out for me was the attention to the character behaviors. From the way Tousaka prances her way across the screen to Ilya's effortless, innocent expression while telling Berserker to kill others, the subtle details really show that they went the extra effort to make this truly a work of art.


You won't be disappointed in the action department either. The battles here, though brief, are amazing to behold. From the smoke that billows around Saber's invisible sword to the bright sparks from clashing blades and shockwaves after body attacks- everything is top notch. Granted, if you don't like gore and blood, some parts of the show may be a bit dark, but assuming that you survived F/Z you should be fine here. Ecchi is really not a focus here, and despite the H-nature of the original VN, you won't be seeing a lot of skin ship between Shirou and Tousaka. That being said, an embarrassed Tousaka in brassiere hugging a pillow is perhaps adequate recompense.


Sound:

As much as I hate to say it, I prefer the music in the original FSN and F/Z to the work here. There are definitely throwbacks to the original such as the reuse of Disillusion as an insert song, but the OP/EDs and BGM just aren't as memorable. The show has a total of two OPs and two EDs. The first OP has some good vibes but doesn't have the mystery or strong melody of Disillusion. The second OP comes across similarly; it's a decent OP but feels a bit slow considering the show's brisk pacing. Ufotable's association with Kalafina continues with both the EDs, the second of which is the stronger of the two.


The VA cast should be familiar to those who watched the original. As far as I could tell, the entirety of the original cast returns for this grand reunion. Despite the almost decade since the first FSN, everyone sounds as you'd expect- perhaps only even better given their seasoned experience. Regardless, Kana Ueda is hands down the queen of this show, and gives an absolutely superb performance.


Story:

Emiya Shirou has never known happiness; he felt that he never deserved any as the sole survivor of the great fire at the end of Fate/Zero. As fate would have it, this novice user of magic (and adopted son of Emiya Kiritsugi) happens to witness a battle between servants and is literally forced into being a master. Luckily, due to his catalyst, he unknowingly summons the strongest of the servants - Saber. However, will her strength be enough to balance out her master's weaknesses? Doubly lucky, Shirou finds that one of his schoolmates (Tousaka) is also a master. Despite her initial assistance, how long will her help continue given that this is a battle royale?


The show starts with a brutal, hectic introduction with an engaging yet strikingly similar plot to the original FSN. Pacing is quite masterful as the show does a great job of balancing action-packed episodes with breathers to fill in more background. The central plotline mirrors that in the UTW movie but does a bit more to explore of side plots. For example, Ilya gets a nice episode that connects well to the events of Fate/Zero. However, there isn't as much of a balance in terms of exposition compared to the original FSN, and the master/servant relationships and mechanics of the battle for the grail are somewhat glossed over. There is really only one single story line, though there is a bit of a rise in intensity to mark the end of the first season.


If I had to pick what was the strongest facet of the story, it would have to be the execution. The background, interactions, and events all built throughout the show until the final glue of the epilogue ties it all together. The weakest aspect is Archer's decision-making; let's just say that there were plenty of chances to carry out his original mission. Overall, the show has a strong, but not flawless story.


Character:

A lot hasn't changed from the original FSN. Emiya is still self-sacrificing, Shinji is still the turd, and Gilgamesh still refers to everyone else as "mongrels". What has changed is the drastic shift in focus towards Tousaka, Archer, and (to a lesser extent) Caster. I was actually rather disappointed in the amount of progress in the Shirou/Tousaka relationship, it all felt somewhat juvenile, especially compared to the relationships in Fate/Zero (granted they are much younger here I guess). That aside, the main cast is definitely a dynamic set that grows and adapts throughout the show. Again, the real gems of the show for me were in the small details that weren't in the original; these include scenes like Tousaka getting flustered and Saber's adorable inability to use a bat in a batting cage. Really, the rating for this section will highly depend on how you mesh with the above-mentioned characters. Luckily, for me, the show had my basis covered.


Value:

FSN is an entertaining addition... er... partial addition to the Fate animated universe. Though it doesn't add much more in terms of story to the UBW movie, it does add some interesting character tidbits. And the production, by itself, should make it worth your time. As for re-watch, once you understand the main twist, it's funny re-watching and seeing the irony in a lot of the character lines. Despite the intense expectations coming after Fate/Zero, I think Type Moon delivered a strong hit, definitely check this one out.

So let me get this out of the way: Fate/Zero is one of my favorite anime of all time and one of the finest examples of the medium I can come up with in the past ten years. Despite many flaws, the story was gritty and intense, the characters well-rounded and enjoyable, and the sparse action scenes were fantastic. So it’s only natural I’d go into Fate/Stay Night with huge expectations.
Despite being a fan of Fate/Zero I’ve never been able to watch Fate/Stay Night because of how…well, crappy it is. The writing is awful, the animation isn’t that great, and I’ve never found it tobe a compelling package, even with the Fate name strapped on. And then there’s the abominable Fate/Kaleid series that is, by the way, getting a third season despite shitting all over everything that Fate/Zero built up and making this serious series into a joke.


Unlimited Blade Works has a film version that I never got around to watching, so this is all new to me. The series itself is based on a different branch of the visual novel, so there will be a lot of similarities to the first Fate anime, but it does diverge at one point.


For those who don’t know the gist of Fate, every once in a while there is a Holy Grail War officiated by the church. In this war, seven mages summon Heroic Spirits, heroes of myth and legend, who duke it out in life or death battles. When one Spirit (also called Servant) is standing, the Holy Grail appears and wishes are granted to the winner.


Everyone participating in the war gets three command seals which magically compel their Servant to do whatever they wish. Once the seals run out, they have very little control over what their Servant does next.


Unlimited Blade Works takes place ten years after the Fourth Holy Grail War and follows the children of that battle’s contestants. As such, they’re all (for the most part) in high school.


Blade Works opens when Rin Tohsaka, daughter of a man killed in thelast war, summons an Archer-class Servant who dukes it out with a Lancer-class after school one night. A young kid named Shirou Emiya, adopted son of the now deceased master of Saber in the previous war, bears witness to the battle and is chased down and killed by Lancer. Somehow, he is brought back to life by Rin and he summons Saber to fight for him in the Fifth Holy Grail War. Joining this battle is the daughter of Emiya Kiritsugu as well as a few surprise characters.


Shirou and Rin wind up forming an alliance to take down the other Servants and that’s pretty much the extent of the plot of this first half of the series. The two battle against the bad guys, go to school, and develop a cute romance.


Compared to Fate/Zero I felt the series paced itself a lot better. Probably my biggest problem with Zero was how slow it was to get to the action. But that complaint will be a double-edged sword as I loved the cast in Fate/Zero and felt that the story’s focus on adult characters (for the most part) made it much more compelling to me. Unlimited Blade Works is focused on teenagers, which I thought would alienate me. The high school setting made me nearly groan, figuring it’d fall into the conventions of the place. God forbid Saber be dressed as a schoolgirl and made an “exchange student”.


But Fate handles the setting really well with teenage characters who aren’t conventional enough in thought and action to make me quit. Shirou is an interesting guy who is learning magic as best he can, doesn’t really want to be a part of the War as it was the catalyst for him becoming who he is, and also has developed a caring for Saber despite her being a weapon essentially. And the same can be said of Rin, who cares deeply for her Servant as well as Shirou, hides the fact she is an emotional and somewhat impulsive girl behind her supposed love for magic, and really is seeking an acceptance that her lonely life most likely hasn’t given her. These are kids who were bred specifically to fight in a war and living in the shadows of the dead.


That’s not to say that the character’s are totally deep in any way, but I enjoyed their company and constant readers know that Rin ranks as one of my favorite, if not my favorite tsundere, of all time. Rin isn’t tsundere enough to be a bitch, nor annoying enough in what she says to turn you away. She has her “character trope” moments, but she also has a sweet side the show likes to shine a light on.


Despite all that, compared to the characters of Fate/Zero, Unlimited Blade Works is lacking the interesting cast that kept me so glued to my seat. But Zero liked to jump around to characters and have huge swathes of development and talking rather than action, something that did detract from it for me and something Unlimited Blade Works rectifies. Action scenes are plentiful and gorgeous. No action scene in this show is poorly done; I’d go so far as to say that this is the best action of any anime I’ve ever watched.


And this is mostly thanks to the ridiculously beautiful animation. Every episode is film quality with beautiful colors, meticulously detailed backgrounds, and usually pretty character design. Faces can be a little strange, especially from the side, but it’s still of a quality few if any anime strive for nowadays.


When the action heats up, the animation never misses a beat–it’s damn near impossible to explain how amazing the animation for these action scenes are. You can feel every hit, even when the fighters are crossing swords at a hundred miles an hour. It’s freaking amazing the detail in these battles.


And music? The opening and closing credits aren’t anything memorable but the soundtrack of the show is pretty good and works will with the intense action.


I occasionally spoil the shit out of anime to tear apart the plot or complain about characters but I’m loathe to do so with a show as good as Unlimited Blade Works. If you haven’t watched it, quit watching whatever you’re watching and get ready for the best anime I’ve seen out of 2014. The dialogue is great, the characters are memorable, the plot is an anime classic, and the entire package is presented in a format that appears directed like a film and has the production value of such.


The worst part about this show? Knowing nothing you watch after it will  likely satisfy you. And also having to wait till April to see how the series continues.


…I know I can cheat and read about the game and watch the movie and all that but I won’t. I’m stubborn like that.

This review isn't well structured, i don't know how to structure movie/show reviews but here goes... at roughly the 1 hour mark i decided to watch the rest sped up but slow enough to read the subs but with lightning fast japanese audio. it felt like the story was just going in 1 direction, getting tenser and tenser but rarely relieving the tension, and when it does it doesn't do it very well imo, pacing is a bit too slow i feel, they could of been more light moments and in more places to break it up more. the characters didn't really feel engaging, i'man emotional person and i was just like "whatever" mentally. imo too much of a focus on fight scenes, like a deathcore song with too much of a focus on breakdowns it achieves the same effect with me, some fight scenes are probably too long winded, the fight scenes do have really good visuals. the animation is very good... animation:8. story:5. music.8. overall score:6.

The premise of this show was what intrigued me most, the style of magic that exists in the show's universe and the idea of the whole Holy Grail war. Despite many flaws, I found Fate/Stay Night highly entertaining. 
The 40-minute episode format was refreshing, and the art and animation gorgeous. At the same time as I found the logic to be inconsistent and confused, I still liked the tactical nature of their battles and alliances, and the world building that happened.
The many historical cameos were the best thing about the show by far.
As I was watching this show, not knowing anything about the type-moon visualnovel or their entire expanded universe, I found myself  wanting to know more about this world and why it felt like there were so many hidden subplots. Compelled, I spent hours online looking up the mythology of the type-moon universe, which is a credit to some engaging storytelling on their part, even though I question some of the trope-riddled and mushy plot.\n\n
From my own scoring system:\n\n
2/3 for characters & relationships\n
2/3 for plot and storytelling\n
3/3 for formal elements\n
0/1 for my special award

Two very important things we can all learn from Shirou Emiya. First, did you know people die when they are killed. Also just because you got something correct doesn't actually mean you're right.
Enough with the Shirou Emiya quote and lets get into the review. I will be reviewing the series as a whole instead of 1st then 2nd season.
Story: 8/10
The story is exactly the same as the original Fate Stay Night. Shirou gets involved in the Holy Grail war somehow and now must fight and survive the war using his personal Saber waifu (just kidding). Even though the story is the same, it originally isstill a great story for survival anime.


Characters:9/10

I really do love the characters of the Fate series. Shirou Emiya: he' a little on the cliche protagonist side, but he's my favorite of those. Rin Tohsaka is my favorite tsundere, even though I generally don't like tsunderes. And do I even have to say anything for Saber. Even though I hate Gilgamesh, because I hate him actually makes the anime a lot more enjoyable and satisfying.


Enjoyment: 10/10

The enjoyment was FREAKING AAAAMAAAAZIIIIING!!!!!!!! I loved the action scenes cause they were just made so well. I do want to come back to the plot for a bit. The plot was the same as the original Fate Stay Night, but the outcoming was completely and totally different, especially in the second season. I'm not gonna tell you how it was different cause of spoilers, but I'll just say it was very different and a lot better. Also I think Shirou and Rin make a better couple than Shirou and Saber. Which means that leaves poor little Saber prone to all those waifu hungry otakus.


Art and Sound: 10/10

The art is my favorite art style of the modern anime era and the sound and soundtrack are just splendid. I love the OST of the Fate series, cause it's just so enhanced and it fits very well too. I also think the dub is one of the best dubs I've watched.


Overall: 9/10

Fate Stay Night UBW is one of my favorite animes ever and I say it's definitely a watch. It's not a perfect anime because the plot is still the same as the original, but Fate Stay Night UBW is still a great anime to watch. It also has a lot of major plot twists like Fate Zero. Definitely go watch the dub, cause it's one of the best dubs I've ever watched. I hope you'll love it as much as I did. Thx for reading.

Story 7/10: Being an alternate route to the original Fate/Stay Night, one shouldn't expect a whole lot more. In relation to Shirou and Sabre, the MC's of the original... it somehow got leagues stupider in every way and kinda answered questions that I personally couldn't care less about. It even managed to make him even more overpowered, which was severely aggravating.
Literally everyone else in the story is done fantastically though, so it begrudgingly drags it up quite a few notches. Literally everyone else done in a fantastic way... the Fate/Zero way.
Art 10/10: Great quality with action scenes notably running at a higher framerate that resultsin much nicer animation.


Sound 8/10: Having better sound quality is one thing, but it was also done leagues better. Berserker is notably no longer or gargling mouthwash, instead he is a proper howling monster. Music could have been better, but I digress.


Enjoyment 7/10: I wanted to enjoy it as much as Fate/Zero, but I could only enjoy the return of characters that served as little more than plot devices and the animation quality. The story was... as contrived as ever when it came to winning any sort of fight which detracted from the enjoyment. Being dragged out of enjoying something into borderline regret is pretty bad.


Overall 7/10: Much better than the Original Fate/Stay Night, but in terms of the main characters from the original... it got needlessly edgy, over-complicated, and somehow worse. Luckily the story tries to focus more on a secondary characters perspective and their involvement, but even they get swallowed up by it towards the end.

The concept of an adaptation is too adept (no shit) be that a book, visual novel, comic, etc. into a moving picture. One thing an adaptation should do is try and stay faithful to the source material while doing things differently from said source material so that it may stand on its own feet. But can a 2 cour adaptation of a single route from a 50+ hour visual novel achieve that?
For the sake of those that have experience with this franchise such as myself I’ll be doing a two part review. One from the people who don’t even know what Fate/Stay Night is (UNX),and one for those who’ve either read the visual novel or seen the previous Fate anime entries (EXP), and please keep in mind that I’m a little bit of a fanboy when it comes to this series. Nevertheless I’ll try to approach both views free of bias (I did say try).


The Short Version:

(UNX):

(+)The animation, good god the animation.

(+)The music.

(-)You’ll be wondering what all the fuss, more than once throughout the runtime.

(EPX):

(+)Pretty much the entire show.

(-)Some of the things they added, because HOW DARE THEY?!


The Story (UNX (7/10) EXP (8/10)): For those initiates among you this show will seem like a god damn shit storm half the time, The first two episode are double the length of your standard anime, and the only real reason for this is to give a massive exposition dump of the world and rule set you’ve just stepped into. 


This is the reason a lot of new comers are, to put it lightly, off put as fuck to continue watching the series, you’ve got the entire concept of Heroic Spirits and the Holy Grail to contend with, the explanation of the rule set given to the mages, and almost the exactly same outline of events from two different people. Welcome to the Type-Moon way of doing things kids, enjoy the ride, but this extremely slow start shouldn’t make you drop this series because you’ll find as the show goes on, its gets just a little bit good. Just a little.


For the fans this slow start is probably expected, and the first episode itself is a little bit of fan service, because it’s the entire prologue of the visual novel, then again they are parts of the story that aren’t in the visual novel. Most of that is in S2 though so let’s stay focused. You can argue for both sides when you say that the pacing of the show is flawed and the concept of the Holy Grail War itself doesn’t even present itself unlike a certain prequel to this show, the fact that it’s supposed to be a full on battle royale. Except that you only see this “battle royale” is seen from one side and gives more of a “Me against the world” vibe.


Another problem with this show is that if you’re really observant during the first two episode you’ll spot one of the major plot elements of this entire route/show, given what happens in the episodes towards the end, you’ll be able to guess it if you’re lucky. I suppose the action scenes should be mentioned, and this goes from both parties when I say that they’re some of the best we’ll ever, because they have such a sense of impact. Every time a hit lands you feel the weight of said blow, and that’s something that very hard to do given that some of the fights are little more than a couple of fast moving blurs. 


The ending itself so obvious sets up for a sequel that it’s almost painful, almost. The amount of rage and hype is generated at the time was fucking hilarious, but let’s be glad that nowadays you can move straight to S2 without any hassle.


The Characters (UNX (6/10) EPX (8/10)): The characters, or rather, the main character of this show will be unpopular with the any newcomers to say the least. He’s such a hard-line Idealistic that it’s annoying, even when a much more sensible course of action is present he’ll take the moral victory over the logical victory. For the EXP we wouldn’t accept anyone but this hopeless, loveable idiot as the lead of this show.


Shirou Emiya: The annoying prick from above, and a hopeless bastard.


Rin Tohshaka: Main chick for this route and the much more capable mage than Shirou.


Saber: Servant to Shirou and an undisputed god of combat.


Archer: Main source of conflict for Shirou and has his fair share of epic fighting moments.


With regards to the other characters of the show, only some of them will that any real impact in the show while others are literally there for one purpose and nothing else. Both side will definitely, definitely have a problem with these characters. Keep in mind however that this is a single route of a massive visual novel, you should have expected this.


Art & Sound (UNX (9/10) EPX (8/10) & (8/10) 8/10): For both new comers and experienced veterans the animation that ufotable put into this show is top tier shit, but the reason UNX would be more daseled by it would be because ufotable does a great job at their lighting and blending of 3D & 2D, but when you stop and stare at it for longer than you should. You realize that it’s just more shadows than usual of on the characters and environment, that and it’s generally a lot darker than the standard anime.


The sound however of both sides is more than exceptional, the entire OST should be bought by everyone, end of story.


What do you think of this anime?


Really? You’re asking a fan-boy who spend $260 on a limited edition boxset that question?


Would you recommend this anime?


For the UNX sure. For the EPX on two conditions; don’t expect the full package of the visual novel and don’t expect another Fate/Zero.


Goodbye my brethren, see you in the next one.
